Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Homelessne.Homelessness_with_annotation: In Kasedashi City, Kagoshima, torrential downpours broke the embankment of the Kaseda River, flooding houses and establishments near the area.
The Kuma River in Kumamoto Prefecture also overflowed, destroying 209 houses and flooding 2,647 more.
A rainfall amount of 59.8 inches in Ebino, Miyazaki Prefecture were recorded causing widespread landslides, which killed 69 individuals.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Olive was an erratic and slightly long-lived tropical cyclone that impacted Japan and affected Manchuria during early-August 1971.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: 90 deaths were attributed from Olive, with the majority in Japan.

Total_Death_Per_Country.Death_with_annotation: Total deaths from Olive in Japan were at 69, while the damages were unknown.
Reports from different institutions and agencies, including Seoul's National Disaster Relief Center, said that Olive killed 27 in the country, all due to unknown reasons.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: A rainfall amount of 59.8 inches in Ebino, Miyazaki Prefecture were recorded causing widespread landslides, which killed 69 individuals.
Reports from different institutions and agencies, including Seoul's National Disaster Relief Center, said that Olive killed 27 in the country, all due to unknown reasons.

Total_Insured_Damage_Per_Country.Total_Insured_Damage_Assessment_with_ann: Total deaths from Olive in Japan were at 69, while the damages were unknown.
Reports from different institutions and agencies, including Seoul's National Disaster Relief Center, said that Olive killed 27 in the country, all due to unknown reasons.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Insured_Da.Insured_Damage_Assessment_with_annotatio: In Kasedashi City, Kagoshima, torrential downpours broke the embankment of the Kaseda River, flooding houses and establishments near the area.
The Kuma River in Kumamoto Prefecture also overflowed, destroying 209 houses and flooding 2,647 more.
The dam in the prefecture, namely Ichifusa Dam, also released large amounts of water to avoid failure, flooding its lake and destroying some houses nearby.
A rainfall amount of 59.8 inches in Ebino, Miyazaki Prefecture were recorded causing widespread landslides, which killed 69 individuals.

Total_Displacement_Per_Country.Displacement_with_annotation: The typhoon heavily disrupted the activities of the 13th World Scout Jamboree, which was held in Fujinomiya, Shizuoka Prefecture from August 2 to 10, also the week when Olive formed. The rains started to pour on August 3, but this is due to an existing front. The aftermath of the rains caused floods that reached their campsite. in Mount Fuji. As a result, the Japanese Boy Scout Officials there ordered the mandatory evacuations of the scouts to an unknown place.

Total_Economic_Damage_Per_Country.Total_Economic_Damage_Assessment_with_an: Total deaths from Olive in Japan were at 69, while the damages were unknown.
Despite not making landfall at any part of South Korea, Olive caused damages on the southern coasts of the country.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Economic_D.Economic_Damage_Assessment_with_annotati: In Kasedashi City, Kagoshima, torrential downpours broke the embankment of the Kaseda River, flooding houses and establishments near the area.
The Kuma River in Kumamoto Prefecture also overflowed, destroying 209 houses and flooding 2,647 more.
The dam in the prefecture, namely Ichifusa Dam, also released large amounts of water to avoid failure, flooding its lake and destroying some houses nearby.
A rainfall amount of 59.8 inches in Ebino, Miyazaki Prefecture were recorded causing widespread landslides, which killed 69 individuals.
All transportations, including train services, air traffic, sea services and shipping were suspended and affected, while incomplete reports said that 77 roads throughout Kyushu were destroyed.

Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Wind: The system had a good outflow, as being evidenced by radar imagery.[2] Olive then slightly moved to the west-northwest before taking a north-northwestward track due to the weakness of another subtropical ridge, which was located near the Philippines.[2] The system also slowed down, before intensifying to a severe tropical storm at 18:00 UTC on the next day as the forward motion of the storm speeded.[1] Another ridge pulled the system to the northwest before again, slowing down as Olive became poorly defined on satellite images.[1][2] On 12:00 UTC on August 1, the CMA upgraded the system to a minimal typhoon based on an estimate of 68 knots and an emerging eye; however, the JTWC only elevated the system's intensity to typhoon status at the same time on the next day.[1][2] The system then accelerated to the northwest before intensifying further to a Category 2 typhoon at 12:00 UTC on August 3 and reached its peak intensity shortly, with maximum sustained winds of 155 km/h (95 mph) and an unusually low minimum barometric pressure of 935 mbar, as being recorded by a reconnaissance aircraft.[2]
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Rainfall: A conducted research about Olive reported that the rain more dominated than the winds, classifying the system as a rain typhoon.[6] Heavy inundation damages were also seen throughout the southern part of Japan.[1] The Yakushima Station in Yakushima Island reported winds up to 80 knots and a minimum pressure of 938.7 mb, while no reports of damages were seen.[2] In Kasedashi City, Kagoshima, torrential downpours broke the embankment of the Kaseda River, flooding houses and establishments near the area.[7] The Kuma River in Kumamoto Prefecture also overflowed, destroying 209 houses and flooding 2,647 more.[8] The dam in the prefecture, namely Ichifusa Dam, also released large amounts of water to avoid failure, flooding its lake and destroying some houses nearby.[2] A rainfall amount of 59.8 inches in Ebino, Miyazaki Prefecture were recorded causing widespread landslides, which killed 69 individuals.[2][9][10]
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Flood: Heavy inundation damages were also seen throughout the southern part of Japan.[1] The Yakushima Station in Yakushima Island reported winds up to 80 knots and a minimum pressure of 938.7 mb, while no reports of damages were seen.[2] In Kasedashi City, Kagoshima, torrential downpours broke the embankment of the Kaseda River, flooding houses and establishments near the area.[7] The Kuma River in Kumamoto Prefecture also overflowed, destroying 209 houses and flooding 2,647 more.[8] The dam in the prefecture, namely Ichifusa Dam, also released large amounts of water to avoid failure, flooding its lake and destroying some houses nearby.[2]
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Landslide: A rainfall amount of 59.8 inches in Ebino, Miyazaki Prefecture were recorded causing widespread landslides, which killed 69 individuals.[2][9][10] The avalanche also destroyed houses and injured 209 persons, with the majority are because they are rescued from getting trapped in their houses.[2]

Total_Building_Damage_Per_Country.Building_Damage_with_annotation: Heavy inundation damages were also seen throughout the southern part of Japan.
Flash floods and widespread landslides were also seen.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Building_D.Building_Damage_with_annotation: In Kasedashi City, Kagoshima, torrential downpours broke the embankment of the Kaseda River, flooding houses and establishments near the area.
The Kuma River in Kumamoto Prefecture also overflowed, destroying 209 houses and flooding 2,647 more.
The dam in the prefecture, namely Ichifusa Dam, also released large amounts of water to avoid failure, flooding its lake and destroying some houses nearby.

A rainfall amount of 59.8 inches in Ebino, Miyazaki Prefecture were recorded causing widespread landslides, which killed 69 individuals. The avalanche also destroyed houses and injured 209 persons, with the majority are because they are rescued from getting trapped in their houses.
All transportations, including train services, air traffic, sea services and shipping were suspended and affected, while incomplete reports said that 77 roads throughout Kyushu were destroyed.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Affected.Affected_with_annotation: In Kasedashi City, Kagoshima, torrential downpours broke the embankment of the Kaseda River, flooding houses and establishments near the area.
The Kuma River in Kumamoto Prefecture also overflowed, destroying 209 houses and flooding 2,647 more.
A rainfall amount of 59.8 inches in Ebino, Miyazaki Prefecture were recorded causing widespread landslides, which killed 69 individuals.
The typhoon heavily disrupted the activities of the 13th World Scout Jamboree, which was held in Fujinomiya, Shizuoka Prefecture from August 2 to 10, also the week when Olive formed.
A rainfall amount of 390.8 mm and a total of 444.0 mm were recorded at Samcheok, Gangwon Province.
Ulleungdo recorded the lowest barometric pressure from the storm at 976.2 hPa and the fastest instantaneous wind speed from Olive, at 32.0 m/s.
Pohang reported the fastest wind speed, at 19.3 m/s.
Reports from different institutions and agencies, including Seoul's National Disaster Relief Center, said that Olive killed 27 in the country, all due to unknown reasons.
